# Chord: Dominant 7b5 in C (Shape: G)

## Brief Presentation
The Dominant 7b5 chord, also known as the half-diminished 7th chord, is a four-note chord that combines the dominant 7th (♭7) and diminished 5th (♭5) intervals. In the key of C, this chord has a G shape when played on the guitar. It has a dissonant and ambiguous sound, often adding tension and complexity to a musical piece.

## Notes and Intervals
- Root: G
- Major 3rd (♯3): B
- Diminished 5th (♭5): D
- Minor 7th (♭7): F

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The Dominant 7b5 chord is commonly used in jazz and blues music to create tension and add color to progressions. It has a dark and mysterious quality due to the dissonance created by the diminished 5th interval. This chord can evoke a sense of suspense and intrigue in a musical composition.

## Songs
Here are three songs that feature the Dominant 7b5 chord in their chord progressions:
1. "So What" by Miles Davis - This iconic jazz piece features the Dominant 7b5 chord prominently in its modal progression.
2. "All Blues" by Miles Davis - Another classic jazz tune that makes use of the Dominant 7b5 chord to add depth and richness to the harmony.
3. "Blue Monk" by Thelonious Monk - In this blues composition, the Dominant 7b5 chord is used to create a bluesy and soulful sound.

This chord adds a unique flavor to music, making it a valuable tool for composers and musicians looking to explore more adventurous harmonic possibilities.
